Description of incident: A database containing names, account              numbers and customer passwords was stolen. A credit-card encoder and              software to encode the information onto blank cards was also used              to acquire information from ATMs. A former programmer at Birmingham,              Ala.-based Compass Bank stole a hard drive containing 1 million customer              records and used some of that information to commit debit-card fraud.              The thief had used the information stolen from Compass Bank's database              to create about 250 counterfeit debit cards. He was able to use about              45 of those cards to access and withdraw cash from customer accounts              at the bank before he was arrested.
